title: Why is the black hole theory important? - Quora

response.answer_text: Black hole studies are super important because black holes have the power to [indirectly] create, sustain and destroy anything in the universe. Create and destroy really just mean transform. They are observed to be the most massive, powerful and luminous “objects” in the entire universe. If they weren’t so gravitationally powerful and if they allowed light to escape constantly, they’d always look like the brightest stars in the universe, and we’d see them with our own eyes in the center of almost every galaxy. Because that’s not the cause, we only occasionally see them light up and that’s called a “quasar.”  So they are not only the most powerful, massive, and potentially luminous but they are also consistently in the center of all the action! They are at the heart or in the navel (middle) of almost all of the largest structures in the universe (galaxies).  The term “black hole” is so misleading because they typically contain more light/energy/matter than stars, and they are intensely full/condensed/massive. They contain gravitational singularities. Studying black holes may lead to understanding how the universe itself was “born” from a gravitational singularity. Thus black holes may contain the deepest secrets of the universe and its beginnings. A self-study of astrophysics lead me realize that in my childhood/family religion (Hinduism), Supermassive black holes were worshiped as the primal manifestations of God represented by Shiva/Vishnu/Brahma/Krishna etc... I was happy to realize this, because I was indoctrinated with concepts like God was the most powerful, luminous, creative, sustaining, destroying person/force in the universe and was manifested in the center of every mini-universe (galaxy). The sages may have tricked us into worshiping supermassive black holes and gravity, for good reasons I believe. Hindu temples are built like little galaxies, with God in the center and we “devotees” walking around/circumambulating (orbiting) God. The love between Shiva and Shakti (God/Goddess) is akin to the love play between spacetime/gravity and energy/matter.
